ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK TAR: STU 36462 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
 
 
FOR THE 
 
 
 
SUBREGIONAL CORRIDOR OPERATIONAL EFFICIENCY STUDY 
IN THE SOUTH ASIA SUBREGION  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
July 2003

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
 
ADB    –  Asian Development Bank 
    EDI    –  electronic data interchanges 
    IT    –  information technology 
    RETA    –  regional technical assistance 
    SASEC  –  South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation 
    TIR    –  transport international routier 
  TWG    –  Transport Working Group 
   
 
NOTE 
 
 
    In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by S. Tsukada, Senior Transport Specialist, Transport and 
Communications Division, South Asia Department

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Having  witnessed  increased  momentum  in  the  South  Asia  Subregion  for regional 
economic cooperation (e.g., South Asia free trade area and South Asia growth quadrangle 
concepts), the Asian Development Bank (ADB) decided to extend two-phased regional technical 
assistance (RETA) for South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) to promote 
subregional  cooperation  among  the  countries  there.  In  2001,  four  countries  (Bangladesh, 
Bhutan, India, and Nepal) confirmed their participation in the transport sector component of the 
RETA. With this confirmation, the Transport Working Group (TWG) was established in 2001, 
which carried out the sector overview as part of the  phase I activities. The sector overview 
identified that institutional or operational impediments, together with physical deficiencies of 
systems, greatly hamper efficient operations of subregional corridors, and recommended that an 
in-depth  analysis  be  carried  out  to  identify  corridor-specific  institutional  and  physical 
impediments under phase II activities. The recommendation was endorsed by the Country 
Advisors’ Meeting held in October 2002. A  TA Fact-Finding Mission1 was sent in December 
2002 to Nepal, a hosting country of the TWG activities, to define the scope of the RETA for the 
Subregional Corridor Operational Efficiency Study in the South Asia Subregion (the current 
RETA).2 This paper was prepared based on the findings and understandings of the Mission. The 
logical framework of the RETA is given in Appendix 1. The RETA is included in the 2003 Status 
Report for SARD Subregional Cooperation Strategy and Program.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Transport plays a critical role in subregional economic cooperation. Better transport 
connections would enable SASEC countries to be physically and commercially linked to each 
other. This would potentially serve as a springboard for the future integration of the SASEC 
subregion into the global trade regime.   
 
3.  A salient feature of the subregion is the existence of two landlocked countries, Nepal 
and Bhutan. These countries need access to seaports via India or via India and Bangladesh 
combined. India is important not only as a transit country, but also as a major trading partner for 
these countries. About 50% of Nepalese trade and 90% of Bhutanese trade is to and from India.  
Located in the eastern part of the SASEC region, Bangladesh can provide the landlocked 
countries with alternative access to seaports, and can potentially offer a shortcut to the sea for 
the northeastern states of India.  
 
4.  SASEC  countries  are  connected  with  each  other  through  bilaterally  agreed  upon 
corridors. Many of them are roadbased, such as (i) Kathumandu-Birgunj/Raxaul-Kolkata/Haldia, 
(ii)  Kathumandu-Kharkabhitta-Phulvari/Banglabandh-Dhaka/Mongla,  (iii)  Kolkata-Petrapole/ 
Benapole-Dhakha,  (iv)  Thimpu-Phuensholing/Jaigaon-Kolkata/Haldia,  and  (iv)  Thimpu-
Phuensholing/Jaigoon-Burimari-Dhaka.  Some  are  rail  based,  such  as  Kathumandu-Birgunj-
Mumbai, while some are inland waterway based, such as  Kolkata-Sunderban-(Buramputra 
River)-Assam.  
 
5.  The overall performance of these corridors is not particularly impressive. The time and 
cost required for moving cargo along these corridors are much higher than those of rival 
economies in Asia. For instance, total transport and processing costs of carpet from Kathmandu

to Bremen in Germany are $2,651, of which 55% is the inland leg of transportation and 
processing costs including handling costs at the Port of Kolkata. Another example of inefficient 
cross-border operation is the Kolkata-Petrapol/Benapol-Dhaka corridor, which provides a major 
connection between the eastern part of India and Bangladesh. This 300-kilometer corridor takes 
3–6 days to get Kolkata-originating cargoes to reach Dhaka, which would take 2 days in rival 
economies. Problems are not only time of transportation, but also its unpredictability, thus 
requiring higher levels of inventory at factories and/or warehouses.   
 
6.  This  lower-than-expected  performance  is  due  to  a  number  of  interrelated  factors.  
Administratively, customs clearance and other cross-border inspections are cumbersome and 
time consuming. They are neither transparent nor consistent, which has led to the payment of 
irregular/informal fees and to other rent-seeking activities. Operationally, intermodal operations 
are still in a rudimentary stage. Traditional business relationships play an even more important 
role  than  competition  among  operators/intermediaries  for  lower  prices  and  higher  quality 
services. Indian, Nepalese, and Bhutanese trucks are not allowed to enter into Bangladesh, 
necessitating the transfer of cargoes at the Bangladesh border, while the same restriction is 
applied to Bangladeshi trucks heading to India. Physically, loading and unloading facilities are 
not adequately available at key gateway points. Proper channeling facilities do not exist at the 
key cross-border points, resulting in a long back-up of trucks at the borders. Poor conditions of 
access roads to borders present another impediment to smoother cross-border movement of 
cargoes.  
 
7.  These problems might be resolved by stricter implementation of the current bilateral 
transport/transit agreements.  With streamlined procedures and provision of necessary facilities 
at key cross-border and/or transshipment points, visible improvement may take place. The 
proposed choke point study would look into this issue in detail. In the longer run, the current 
performance of the existing corridors could be significantly improved by the introduction of 
international best practices such as the transport international routier (TIR) carnet system, which 
would  enable  trucks  of  various  nationalities  to  move  across  several  countries,  the 
standardization of documentation requirements, the modernization of inland container transport 
systems,  and  the  introduction  of  information  technology  (IT)  such  as  electronic  data 
interchanges (EDI).   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
8.  The overall goal of TWG activities is the establishment of modernized transit/transport 
systems compatible with international practices so that the SASEC subregion can be effectively 
integrated in the global trade scheme. This will require review of the trade logistic systems 
connecting  (i)  SASEC  countries  to  each  other,  (ii)  a  landlocked  SASEC  country  to  third 
countries, and (iii) a coastal SASEC country to third countries.  
 
9.  Under this framework, the RETA will aim at identifying specific measures to enhance the 
efficiency of individual subregional corridors with particular emphasis on the solution of choke 
point problems at key land-based and sea-based gateways and removal of institutional and 
operational impediments. The RETA will also aim at developing project concepts so as to 
facilitate future financing by multilateral/bilateral aid agencies.

3
B.   Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The RETA will consist of the following components, to be implemented in sequence:  
 
11.  Part 1: Selection of subregional corridors to be studied under phase II activities. 
The RETA would commence with the selection of subregional corridors. Possible selection 
criteria include (i) corridors that have served the subregion as major physical link, (ii) those that 
would offer alternatives to major subregional physical links with significant cost/time savings, 
and (iii) those that would improve the transport/transit system in the areas at crossroads such as 
West Bengal and Assam. An important element of corridor selection is that these subregional 
corridors have already been included in transit/transport agreements or in other similar bilateral 
agreements.  
 
12.  The consultants will develop a list of possible subregional corridors to be included in the 
SASEC framework. From this list, the consultants will select those corridors to be examined in 
the  phase  II  study.  The  total  number  of  corridors  to  be  studied  will  not  exceed  six  in 
consideration of the limited availability of time and resources. These lists will be examined and 
finalized in a workshop to be held before proceeding to field visits. The workshop will be 
composed of one representative from each member country, the consultants, and ADB staff.  
 
13.  Part 2: Evaluation of operational efficiency of individual subregional corridors. 
The  consultants  will  assess  the  operational  efficiency  of  each  subregional  corridor  in  the 
following manner: 
 
(i)  Review  and  describe  current  bilateral/trilateral/other  transit  arrangements  for 
each subregional corridor. 
 
(ii)  Review and analyze the entire process of transporting and processing cargoes 
from an originating point to a final destination point. The analysis will include a 
rough estimation of processing times/days and costs of processing at each stage 
of the activities. This will be done through discussion with transport operators, 
freight forwarders, and/or other intermediaries and also through review of existing 
studies and papers. 
 
(iii)  Benchmark the current performance of individual subregional corridors against 
regional best practices. 
 
(iv)  Based on the analysis, identify major choke points and institutional/operational 
impediments.  
 
14.  Part 3: Choke point analysis. Congestion often takes place at gateway points, both 
land-based  and  sea-based.  Solution  of  this  problem  requires  cooperation  between  both 
countries concerned. Analyses will be carried out from a traffic engineering viewpoint, and also 
in terms of adequacy of cargo-handling facilities and effectiveness of the operational procedures 
of cargo-handling and inspection facilities. Cargo movements and channeling facilities will be 
examined from both sides of the border to ensure smooth cross-border movements of cargo. 
Choke points to be analyzed will be selected based on the recommendation by the  operational 
efficiency  evaluation  study  (possible  choke  points  would  include,  for  instance, 
Benapole/Petrapole  gateways,  Birgunj/Raxaul  gateways,  Kharkabhitta-Phulvari/Banglabandh 
land bridge, Kolkata/Haldia Port, and Chittagong Port).

4  
15.  Part  4:    Institutional  and  operational  impediment  analysis.  Institutional  and 
operational impediments are the major causes of the poor performance of the existing corridors. 
Analysis will be carried out with regard to whether these impediments can be removed by 
stricter enforcement of existing bilateral transit arrangements. Similar analysis will be carried out 
with regard to whether advanced IT or operation/management systems (which are widely used 
in  the  world)  can  bring  about  significant  improvement  of  performance.  Those  IT  or 
operation/management  systems  to  be  examined  include  EDI,  the  TIR  carnet  system, 
standardized  shipment  documents,  and  other  appropriate  technologies  and  systems.  The 
applicability of these technologies and systems will be determined out on both a system-wide 
basis and corridor-by-corridor basis.   
 
16.  Part 5: Development of project/program concepts. Based on the above analyses, the 
consultants  will  develop  concepts  for  specific  projects  or  programs  to  be  financed  by 
multilateral/bilateral aid agencies or by the governments in the subregion. The consultants will 
also identify investment opportunities by the private sector. The projects/ programs to be 
developed will not necessarily need to entail the participation of more than one country. Those 
that are implemented by one country within its territory but with significant implication for 
subregional cooperation may be included in the recommended projects or programs.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
17.  The total cost of the RETA is estimated at $250,000 equivalent, which includes foreign 
exchange costs of $189,600 and local currency costs of  $60,400 equivalent. The RETA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The detailed cost estimates and 
financing plan are shown in Appendix 2.    
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  The Executing Agency of the RETA will be ADB. The Nepalese Government will be the 
host country for the phase II activities of TWG.  
 
19.  To carry out the RETA, ADB will engage an international consulting firm, using ADB’s 
quality and cost-based selection procedures and in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB on the selection and engagement of 
domestic consultants (a simplified technical proposal method will be used). The task requires 6 
person-months of input of two international consultants (one logistic specialist and one trade 
facilitation specialist), and 6 person-months of input of two domestic consultants (two logistics 
specialists familiar with the local situation).  
 
20.  During the phase II activities, the TWG and Trade and Private Sector Working Group will 
coordinate with each other in their activities to generate synergy between their activities. 
 
21.  The  consultants  should  communicate  with  those  to  be  engaged  for  the  project 
preparatory technical assistance for Market Access and Productivity Growth of the Private 
Sector in Nepal through exchange of information and data. 
 
22.  The RETA will commence in September 2003 and be completed in March 2004. Terms 
of reference for the consulting services are outlined in Appendix 3.  As a part of the assignment, 
the consultants will organize a small working group meeting to be held in a third country outside 
of the SASEC subregion. The consultants will prepare a report summarizing the findings of the 
field visit and analyses. The report will be reviewed by the TWG.

5
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis for 
the Subregional Corridor Operational Efficiency Study in the South Asia Subregion, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix  3 
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The  regional  technical  assistance  (RETA)  for  the  Subregional  Corridor  Operational 
Efficiency Study in the South Asia Subregion will be carried out by a team of consultants 
consisting of an international logistics specialist, an international trade facilitation specialist, and 
two domestic logistics specialists. The international logistics specialist should have extensive 
knowledge of and experience in: (i) transport logistics process, particularly the whole chain of 
inland distribution of containers and externally traded goods; (ii) logistics-related industries such 
as freight forwarding, warehousing, trucking, container freight stations, shipping agencies, and 
customs brokerage; (iii) supply chain analysis, or logistics cost calculation; and (iv) economic 
evaluation of projects. The specialist, who will provide 4 person-months of services, should also 
be familiar with the operations of multilateral aid agencies such as the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) and the World Bank.  
 
2.   The international trade facilitation specialist should also have extensive knowledge of 
and  experience  in  customs  clearance,  other  cross-border  formalities,  shipment-related 
documentation  such  as  bills  of  lading  and  way  bills;  nomenclature  of  externally  traded 
commodities;  handover  procedures  for  containers  between  different  parties;  Transport 
International Routier (TIR) carnet; electronic data interchanges (EDI); and other procedural, 
documentation, and information technology (IT) requirements. S/he will provide 2 person-month 
of services.    
 
3.  The two domestic logistics specialists should be familiar with (i) transport logistics 
process;  (ii)  logistics-related  industries  such  as  freight  forwarding,  warehousing, trucking, 
container freight stations, shipping agencies, and customs brokerage for each of the four 
countries participating in the South Asia Economic Cooperation (SASEC), each covering two 
countries. The total input of the services by these domestic consultants will be 6 person-months.  
 
B.  Tasks 
 
4.  The experts will carry out the following tasks: 
 
1.  Development  of  a  possible  list  of  subregional  corridors  to  be  studied 
  under the phase II activities 
 
5.  The international logistics specialist will prepare a list of possible subregional corridors 
based on the results of the findings of the phase I activities and other studies. Possible selection 
criteria include (i) corridors that have served the subregion as major physical links, (ii) those that 
would offer alternatives to major subregional physical links with significant cost/time savings; 
and (iii) those that would improve the transport/transit system in the areas at crossroads such as 
West  Bengal  and  Assam.  An  important  element  of  the  corridor  selection  is  that  these 
subregional  corridors  have  already  been  included  in  bilateral  transit  and/or  transport 
agreements or in the other similar agreements such as operational agreements between two 
railways.  
 
6.  The international logistics specialist will develop a list of possible subregional corridors to 
be included in the SASEC framework. From this list, the consultant will select those corridors to 
be examined in the phase II study. The total number of corridors to be studied will not exceed 
six in consideration of the limited availability of time and resources.

Appendix 3   9 
2.  Organization of a workshop for the selection of the subregional corridors 
and discussion of the survey process  
 
7.  The international logistics specialist will prepare an inception report setting out the 
planned methodology of the RETA and an implementation schedule. The inception report 
should include the lists of (i) subregional corridors to be included in the SASEC framework, and 
(ii) those to be examined in the RETA.  
 
8.  To finalize these lists, the international logistics specialist will organize a workshop for 
securing the endorsement of members of the Transport Working Group (TWG). The workshop 
will be composed of one representative from each member country, the consultants, and ADB 
staff. It will be held in an appropriate location outside of the four SASEC countries. The 
international logistics specialist will  also seek cooperation from the participating countries on  
field visits to be conducted subsequently. At the end of the workshop, the international logistics 
specialist will prepare a short note summarizing key agreements reached for endorsement by 
the participants.   
 
3.  Evaluation of operational efficiency of individual subregional corridors   
 
9.  The  international  logistics  specialist  will  assess  the  operational  efficiency  of  each 
subregional corridor in the following manner: 
 
(i)  Review  and  describe  current  bilateral/trilateral/other  transit  arrangements  for 
each subregional corridor. 
 
(ii)  Review and analyze the entire process of transporting and processing cargoes 
from an originating point to a final destination along the subregional corridor. The 
analysis  will  include  an  estimate  of  processing  times/days  and  costs  of 
processing at each stage of the activities. The process includes a whole chain of 
activities including (i) loading and unloading operations onto or from trucks/rail 
wagons; (ii) line-haul services by truck or rail; (iii) cargo handling at inland 
container depots or container freight stations; (iv) warehousing and other value- 
added activities such as labeling and packaging; (v) customs inspections and 
other cross-border inspections; and (vi) cargo/container handling operations at 
ports,  but  not  including  sailing  by  oceangoing  vessels.  The  costs  include  (i) 
freight to be paid to trucks/rail/inland water transport operators; (ii) fees to be 
paid to freight forwarders and other intermediaries; (iii) fees to be paid to customs 
brokers,  but  not  including  import/export  duties;  (iv)  insurance  fees;  and 
importantly (v) informal payments in a variety of forms to be paid to authorities to 
expedite the process. This will be done through interviewing transport operators, 
freight forwarders, and/or other intermediaries and also through review of existing 
studies and papers. 
 
(iii)  Evaluate the possible extent of improvement by introducing subregional best 
practices (e.g., those crossing the Bhutan/India border, or container handling at 
JNPT).   
 
(iv)  Based on the analysis, identify major choke points and institutional/operational 
impediments.

10  Appendix  3 
4.  Choke point analysis 
 
10.  Analyses of congestion at gateway points, both land-based and sea-based, will be 
carried out from a traffic engineering viewpoint, and also in terms of adequacy of cargo-handling 
facilities and effectiveness of the operational procedures of cargo-handling  and  inspection 
facilities. Cargo movements and channeling facilities will be examined from both sides of the 
border to ensure smooth cross border movements of cargo. In the case of seaports, analysis 
will encompass not only intraport facilities but also those located in their immediate vicinities.  
Choke points to be analyzed will be selected based on the recommendation by the operational 
efficiency  evaluation  study  (possible  choke  points  would  include,  for  instance, 
Benapole/Petrapole  gateways,  Birgunj/Raxaul  gateways  (particularly  road-based  gateway 
points  rather  than  rail-based  points),  Kharkabhitta-Phulvari/Banglabandh  land  bridge, 
Kolcatta/Haldia Port, and Chittagong Port. The international logistics specialist should develop 
an overall plan for improving the flow of cargo between two sides of the border for each choke 
point. This would require estimating the current traffic volume passing through border points, 
analysis of the current flow of traffic, assessment of cargo-handling capacity of the existing 
facilities for transshipment, identification of better channeling mechanisms, and development of 
new traffic schemes together with new investment needs.   
 
5.  Institutional and operational impediment analysis 
 
11.  The  international  logistics  specialist  will  carry  out  an  analysis  of  institutional  and 
operational impediments in existing corridors with regard to whether these impediments can be 
removed by stricter enforcement of existing bilateral transit arrangements. The international 
trade facilitation  specialist will carry out an analysis with regard to whether advanced IT or 
operation/management systems (which are widely used in the world) can bring about significant 
improvement of performance. Those IT or operation/management systems to be examined 
include EDI, TIR carnet system, standardized shipment documents, and other appropriate 
technologies  and  systems.  The  applicability  of  these  technologies  and  systems  will  be 
determined on both a system-wide basis and corridor-by-corridor basis. The international trade 
facilitation  specialist  will  assess  the  adequacy  of  existing  infrastructure  (such  as  the 
telecommunications network) for smooth functioning of these technologies and systems. His/her 
recommendation should include both (i) those technologies and systems that can be introduced 
without  upgrading  the  current  infrastructure,  and  (ii)  those  only  possible  with  upgraded 
infrastructure being put in place.  
 
  6.  Development of project/program concepts 
 
12.  Based on the above analyses, the international logistics and trade facilitation specialists 
will develop concepts for specific projects or programs to be financed by multilateral/bilateral aid 
agencies or by the governments in the subregion. The projects/programs to be developed will 
not necessarily need  to entail the participation of more than one country. Those that are 
implemented by one country within its territory but with significant implication for subregional 
cooperation may be included in the recommended projects or programs.  Possible types of the 
projects or programs include  
 
(i)  an investment project for infrastructure such as road, rail, inland waterway, or  
port;

Appendix 3   11 
(ii)  a  multicomponent  project  for  micro  infrastructure  facilities  such  as  inland 
container  depots,  transshipment  facilities,  improvement  of  telecommunication 
systems, computer systems upgrade, weighing stations or EDI; and 
 
(iii)  a capacity-building technical assistance for (i) training the staff for computer 
systems  such  as  advanced  system  for  customs  declaration  and  approval,  
advanced cargo information system, and/or container inventory management 
system; (ii) provision of training for customs officers and other officials for cross-
border  inspections;  (iii)  introduction  of  accreditation  systems  for  logistics 
specialists through distant learning; and/or (iv) standardization of documentation 
such  as  bills  of  lading,  simplification  of  cross-border  inspections,  and/or 
introduction of TIR carnets for facilitation of cross-border truck movement.  
 
7.  Identification of investment opportunities for the private sector or PPP 
 
13.  The  international  logistics  and  trade  facilitation  specialists  should  also  identify 
investment opportunities for the private sector or the public-private partnership scheme. The 
possible investment opportunities include:  
 
(i)  terminal operation at subregional ports such as Chittagong and Kolkata/Haldia; 
 
(ii)  multimodal operations linking subregional ports to major inland load centers or 
production centers by shipping lines; 
 
(iii)  facilitation  of  the  establishment  of  joint  venture  trucking/freight  forwarding 
operations  with  participation  of  trucking/freight  forwarding  firms  of  different 
nationalities so as to provide seamless operations in both countries;  
 
(iv)  establishment of an international physical distribution center located at or near 
Siliguri where bilaterally licensed trucks may enter into or exit from the center for 
transshipping cargo to other countries’ trucks or vice versa; and 
 
(v)  development of micro infrastructure such as truck terminals, truck parking space, 
warehousing  facilities,  container  freight  stations,  and/or  inland  container 
clearance depots.   
 
8.  Estimate  of  economic  benefits  to  be  realized  through  improvement  of 
individual subregional corridors 
 
14.  The  international  logistics  specialist  will  estimate  the  net  economic  benefits  to  be 
obtained through the improvement of individual subregional corridors based on a specific set of 
assumptions.  
 
C.  Schedule 
 
15.  The schedule for the implementation of the TA, together with the phase II TWG activities 
is as follows: 
 
(i)  preparation of a  draft inception report in September 2003 be sent to ADB for 
review,

12  Appendix  3 
(ii)  small workshop to be held in October 2003 before the consultants are fielded to 
TWG countries, 
 
(iii)  field survey and subsequent analysis to be carried out from October to December 
2003, 
 
(iv)  a draft report in December 2003 to be sent to ADB for review, 
 
(v)  revised draft report to be sent to TWG members in January 2004, 
 
(vi)  TWG meeting in February 2004 to review and endorse the consultants, report, 
 
(vii)  finalization of the consultants’ report in March 2004, and 
 
(viii)  the phase II activities of the TWG to be reported to the country advisors’ meeting.
